title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.001
frontText: Identify the two major types of cloud computing in networking context. ____________ and ____________

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.002
frontText: ____________and ____________ are two key capabilities that enable cloud capability transformation.
backText: Network functions virtualization and software‐defined networking (SDN)

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.003
frontText: TRUE or FALSE: An organization can leverage multiple cloud providers and mix them with computing models to meet enterprise needs.
backText: TRUE: Many enterprises are adopting a multicloud strategy that is more appropriate to pick the right services and integrate them well together.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.004
frontText: ________ provide the right control planes to the right level of controls from the forwarding plane.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.005
frontText: TRUE or FALSE: Cloud infrastructure doesn’t require routers or switches to build the underlying physical network; networking is achieved through logical definitions from SDN.
backText: FALSE: Defining cloud computing networks requires routers and switches to be present in the underlying physical network to define and configure them logically from SDN. Without their physical presence, configuring the logical layer is not possible.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.006
frontText: TRUE or FALSE: Network functions virtualization (NFV) allows network functions to be virtualized without requiring specialized hardware.
backText: TRUE: No specialized additional hardware is required to virtualize network functions in a Microsoft Azure network; this is taken care of by NFV.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.007
frontText: _____________ is a security standard that cannot be guaranteed by cloud architecture as a critical foundation characteristic, but it can be an inherited characteristic of the cloud with additional configurations enabled by the application components.
backText: Zero Trust Standard. It should be implemented by application components using various cloud security features to protect the resources and data handled by the application. This requires implementation teams to invest in the design and cannot be guaranteed by cloud architects as application design can lead to gaps.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.008
frontText: TRUE or FALSE: Azure subscriptions require Microsoft approval to allocate resources.
backText: FALSE: A subscription to Microsoft Azure doesn’t require any approval from Microsoft; they are self‐service capabilities that are enabled through the Internet. No complex contracting procedures are required either.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.009
frontText: ____________ and ____________support multiple virtual networks.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.010
frontText: What is the highest speed Azure ExpressRoute supports?

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.011
frontText: You can secure Azure service resources to a virtual network using ________

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.012
frontText: TRUE or FALSE: Azure allows you to bring your public IP principal from on‐premises networks into Azure.
backText: FALSE: Azure does not support bringing your public IP principal from on‐premises networks into Azure.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.013
frontText: In the Azure networking world, static routing is called __________ and dynamic routing is called ________

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.014
frontText: TRUE or FALSE: Establishing a VPN with Microsoft Azure doesn’t require any encryption.
backText: FALSE: It is essential to encrypt the connection to be secure. Azure doesn’t make encryption an optional configuration item to set up VPNs.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.015
frontText: TRUE or FALSE: An Azure VPN can set up connections between Azure internal networks.
backText: TRUE: VPNs can be used to set up connectivity between internal Azure networks as well. Various configurations options are available within Azure to achieve this configuration.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.016
frontText: TRUE or FALSE: Point‐to‐site VPN type connections support the active‐active DR pattern.
backText: FLASE: Site‐to‐site supports both active‐active and active‐passive, whereas point‐to‐site and ExpressRoute supports only the active‐passive DR pattern.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.017
frontText: Policy‐based VPN devices can support IKE ____________
backText: VERSION 1 (v1): Policy‐based VPN devices support only the IKE v1 protocol.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.018
frontText: TRUE or FALSE: Microsoft recommends setting up a VPN gateway in active‐passive mode.
backText: FALSE: Setting up a VPN gateway in active‐active mode is a Microsoft‐recommended method in which both the IPsec tunnels are simultaneously active, with data flowing through both tunnels simultaneously.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.019
frontText: TRUE or FALSE: Virtual private networks (VPNs) don’t encrypt and hide the information exchanged over the Internet.
backText: FALSE: VPNs do encrypt the data shared over Internet.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.020
frontText: For site‐to‐site VPN, the maximum throughput is ______ GB per tunnel.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.021
frontText: A VPN device on‐premises that comes with public IP addresses is required for _______ VPN connections.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.022
frontText: ___________ is the most preferred method to connect between on‐premises to the Azure network, and it is an exclusive configuration from Azure VPN.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.023
frontText: TRUE or FALSE: Azure ExpressRoute network connectivity can be established through third‐party network connectivity.
backText: TRUE: Third‐party network service providers can establish ExpressRoute configuration to connect from on‐premises to the Azure network.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.024
frontText: TRUE or FALSE: Azure VPN is the right choice to connect Azure and Microsoft 365 services.
backText: FLASE: Microsoft 365 services are available through the Internet. You can also connect to Azure PaaS services from Microsoft 365 services through peering. Azure PaaS services and Microsoft 365 services are connected by Microsoft peering. The Microsoft peering routing domain allows bidirectional connectivity between cloud consumer WANs and Microsoft cloud services. To access Microsoft cloud services, cloud consumers must use public IP addresses owned or controlled by the cloud consumers or by their connectivity providers. They should also adhere to all cloud service regulations.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.025
frontText: TRUE or FALSE: The features of Azure and Microsoft peering are the same.
backText: FALSE: They are distinct services that are applicable for varied contexts. Through Microsoft peering, Microsoft public services such as Microsoft 365, Dynamics 365, and Power Platform are accessed.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.026
frontText: TRUE or FALSE: Enabling peering between Azure public endpoints is an essential first step for customers to access Azure public PaaS and infrastructure services.
backText:
TRUE: The following items must be in place before cloud consumers can connect to Azure services and infrastructure services:
  • Peering between Azure public endpoints is enabled.
  • Each subnet requiring Internet connectivity can be connected to the cloud by using user‐defined routing.
  • Peering paths with Microsoft with routes tagged with appropriate community values will be advertised publicly by Microsoft. Microsoft, however, will not honor any community values tagged to routes advertised to Microsoft.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.027
frontText: ___________ enables you to send traffic directly to a VM within a virtual network.
backText: FastPath: Network traffic is sent directly to virtual machines within the virtual network, bypassing the gateway.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.028
frontText: Microsoft refers to ExpressRoute connections as ___________

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.029
frontText: Azure offers a service via ExpressRoute connectivity at speeds of up to __________.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.030
frontText: Unlimited Data, Metered Data, and the ExpressRoute Premium add‐on are classified as ___________

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.031
frontText: How many virtual networks can an ExpressRoute circuit link?

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.032
frontText: TRUE or FALSE: An ExpressRoute circuit represents a physical connection between cloud consumer on‐premises infrastructure and Microsoft cloud services through a connectivity provider.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.033
frontText: TRUE or FALSE: Difficulties of managing various ExpressRoute circuits start with dynamic routing.
backText: FALSE: It is due to asymmetrical routing.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.034
frontText: TRUE or FALSE: Cloud network administrators can ping default routers within a VNet.
backText: FALSE: Cloud network administrators cannot ping default routers within a VNet.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.035
frontText: TRUE or FALSE: Azure VNets cannot support multicast and broadcast using UDP.
backText: TRUE: Azure VNet does not support multicast or broadcast.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.036
frontText: TRUE or FALSE: Static IP addresses not need to be replaced with dynamic ones before moving the VM from one VNet to another.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.037
frontText: TRUE or FALSE: Azure supports Layer 2 semantics and VNets are Layer 3 overlays.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.038
frontText: TRUE or FALSE: Unlike on‐premises networks, the Azure network does not follow a typical hierarchical structure.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.039
frontText: VM gateways are composed of two or more ___________ deployed to a subnet that you create a gateway subnet with.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.040
frontText: Client‐side ___________ reduces latency by resolving recurring DNS queries from a local cache and improves network resilience to blips.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.041
frontText: TRUE or FALSE: Cloud consumers can register their records manually when Azure‐provided DNS is used.
backText: FALSE: When Azure‐provided name resolution is used, cloud consumers cannot register their records manually.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.042
frontText: TRUE or FALSE: It is not possible to modify the DNS suffix created by Azure‐provided name resolution because it is fully managed by Microsoft.
backText: TRUE: A DNS suffix cannot be changed by cloud consumers in when using Azure‐provided DNS services.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.043
frontText: ____________ is not required when names are resolved within the same cloud service with Azure‐provided DNS services.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.044
frontText: Azure VPN gateways include four components: ________, ___________, __________ and __________
backText: virtual network gateways, local network gateways, connections, and gateway subnets

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.045
frontText: TRUE or FALSE: Site‐to‐site (S2S) VPN gateways allow Azure network engineers to connect securely to a cloud consumer virtual network from another network, whether virtual or physical.
backText: TRUE: A site‐to‐site VPN gateway connection securely connects two networks.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.046
frontText: TRUE or FALSE: In Azure P2S, it is possible to integrate RADIUS with external identity systems.
backText: TRUE: With Azure P2S, RADIUS can be integrated with external identity systems. The P2S VPN opens several authentication options, including multifactor authentication.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.047
frontText: TRUE or FALSE: Windows and Mac users use native VPN clients for P2S.
backText: TRUE: P2S is connected with the native VPN client on Windows and Mac devices. For native clients to connect to Azure, Azure provides a VPN client configuration zip file containing required settings.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.048
frontText: ________________ is used for cross‐region geo‐redundancy and geo‐presence applications and regional multitier applications with administrative or geographic boundaries.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.049
frontText: Virtual hubs utilize which protocol to manage routing between gateways?

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.050
frontText: ______________ contains logging of IKE control messages and events on the gateway while ___________ contains changes to static routes and BGP events.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.051
frontText: ____________ are network hardware devices that forward packets to their destinations.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.052
frontText: Which protocol used in routers determines the fastest and shortest routes to send packets to their destinations?

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.053
frontText: The maximum number of user‐defined routes per route table is ______ , and the maximum number of user‐defined routes per table is _____ for Azure subscriptions.
backText: 200, 400: A user‐defined route table’s maximum limit is 200 and user‐defined routes per route table maximum limit is 400 per Azure subscription.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.054
frontText: In Azure, you can use __________ connection troubleshoot capability to determine routing, filtering, and in‐OS causes of outbound communication problems.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.055
frontText: TRUE or FALSE: Azure networks can combine multiple traffic‐routing methods by nesting Traffic Manager profiles to reap the benefits of multiple traffic‐routing methods.
backText: TRUE: A single Traffic Manager profile may not be able to handle all scenarios. You can use nested Traffic Manager profiles to combine traffic routing methods to benefit from multiple traffic‐routing ways. You can create nested profiles to override the default Traffic Manager behavior, so they can support more extensive and complex traffic routing configurations for cloud consumer applications.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.056
frontText: Azure Traffic Manager supports three types of endpoints: _________, __________, and ______________
backText: Azure endpoints, external endpoints, and nested endpoints

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.057
frontText: Profiles in Azure Traffic Manager can be nested up to ________ levels deep.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.058
frontText: TRUE or FALSE: It is possible to fail any Azure region without affecting Azure Traffic Manager ultimately.
backText: TRUE: In the unlikely event of an outage affecting an entire Azure region, Traffic Manager should continue to operate normally. Application traffic can be directed to an instance of the application that is available in several Azure regions with Traffic Manager.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.059
frontText: Azure Load Balancer has three SKUs: ________, ____________, and ___________

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.060
frontText: TRUE or FALSE: A route table associated with a subnet cannot override the default routes.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.061
frontText: TRUE or FALSE: The WebSocket protocol is not supported by Azure Application Gateway.
backText: FALSE: Azure Application Gateway protocols supported include HTTP, HTTPS, HTTP/2, and WebSocket.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.062
frontText: Which are two primary methods of routing traffic in Application Gateway?

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.063
frontText: TRUE or FALSE: Azure Front Door is a global service and not tied to any specific region.
backText: TRUE: Azure Front Door is deployed globally to all edge locations.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.064
frontText: When evaluating routing rules, Front Door compares ________, __________ and __________
backText: HTTP protocol (HTTP/HTTPS), host, and path matches

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.065
frontText: TRUE or FALSE: Health probes are used to monitor Front Door's back‐end. This is not the case for Application Gateway.
backText: FALSE: Application Gateway Health probes are used to monitor Front Door’s back‐end.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.066
frontText: Availability zones of Azure Load Balancers can be _______, __________, or ________.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.067
frontText: TRUE or FALSE: Additional configurations are required for Azure Application Gateway to monitor the health of resources in its back‐end pool and to remove any resource deemed unhealthy from the pool.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.068
frontText: Azure Front Door is a global, scalable entry point that uses __________ to provide web applications that are fast, secure, and scalable.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.069
frontText: Front Door has many edge environments globally, ranging from ______ to ______ requests per minute.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.070
frontText: _________ removes the requirement to choose a deployment size or instance count when provisioning Application Gateways.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.071
frontText: Microsoft Defender for Cloud streamlines the compliance process using _________

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.072
frontText: When you create a Web Application Firewall (WAF) policy, the WAF policy is in _________ mode by default.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.073
frontText: You can centrally manage multiple Azure Firewall subscriptions using ______________.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.074
frontText: TRUE or FALSE: Azure Sentinel allows cloud consumers to configure NAT rules, network rules, and application rules either by using classic rules or policies.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.075
frontText: Firewall Manager can manage two network architecture types: __________ and __________.
backText: Secured Virtual Hub and Hub Virtual Network

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.076
frontText: With DDoS Protection Standard, three types of attacks are mitigated: ____________, ___________, and ______________.
backText: volumetric attacks, protocol attacks, resource (application) layer attacks.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.077
frontText: TRUE or FALSE: Azure Firewall must be deployed with a public IP address only.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.078
frontText: TRUE or FALSE: ASG Refers to Azure Security Group.
backText: FALSE: ASG Refers to Application Security Group.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.079
frontText: TRUE or FALSE: Creating parent and child firewall policies is not possible in Azure Firewall Manager.
backText: FALSE: It is possible to create nested firewall policies that can be inherited.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.080
frontText: Azure Firewall routes all outgoing traffic to a specified network resource instead of directly to the Internet. What is this type of routing called?

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.081
frontText: Which feature within Azure Firewall Premium service allows you to monitor malicious activity in your network?

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.082
frontText: You can monitor attacks on your web applications with __________

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.083
frontText: The WAF on __________ is global and centralized. Throughout the world, it is deployed at network edge locations.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.084
frontText: TRUE or FALSE: WAF rules that trigger a Detection mode do not block traffic.
backText: TRUE: WAF rules that trigger detection mode are only logged and do not block traffic.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.085
frontText: The Application Gateway WAF provides a detailed report on each threat identified and alerts are recorded in ______ format along with other logs.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.086
frontText: The WAF on a Front Door system is integrated with ________ to track alerts and easily monitor traffic trends.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.087
frontText: In security context, expand SOAR.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.088
frontText: What are two categories of security rules in a WAF policy?
backText: Microsoft‐managed and custom or user‐defined rules

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.089
frontText: TRUE or FALSE: Java attacks and SQL injection attacks are not included in the Azure‐managed Default Rule Set.
backText: FALSE: The Azure‐managed Default Rule Set includes rules for following threat categories: cross‐site scripting, Java attacks, local file inclusion, PHP injection attacks, remote command execution, remote file inclusion, session fixation, SQL injection protection, and protocol attacks.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.090
frontText: What are the actions that Azure WAF cloud consumers can choose to run when a request matches to a rule’s conditions?

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.091
frontText: Cloud consumers can use ______ from their Azure virtual network to access PaaS services and Microsoft Partner services in Azure.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.092
frontText: TRUE or FALSE: On Azure, cloud consumers can have private access to PaaS services and Microsoft Partner services.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.093
frontText: TRUE or FALSE: Though you wanted to use Private Link for Azure PaaS Services, Public endpoints cannot be disabled and they don’t pose any security threat.
backText: FALSE: Public endpoints cannot be disabled and it is good practice to disable unused endpoints.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.094
frontText: TRUE or FALSE: When using Azure Private Links via the Microsoft backbone, Microsoft stores customer data for recovery.
backText: FALSE: Customer data isn’t stored just by enabling Private Links used via the Microsoft backbone.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.095
frontText: A maximum of how many Private Link Service resources can map to a single Private Endpoint interface?

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.096
frontText: TRUE or FALSE: By default, by enabling Private Links for PaaS services, any attack on the resources can be prevented.
backText: FALSE: Public endpoints are available even if private endpoints are enabled; this should be disabled after mapping to the Azure resources to access them privately to prevent and protect from public attacks.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.097
frontText: TRUE or FALSE: Microsoft does not recommend mapping multiple Private Endpoint interfaces to a single resource because it can result in DNS conflicts.
backText: TRUE: Private Link resources should be mapped to only one Private Endpoint.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.098
frontText: Which type of load balancer supports Private Link Service?
backText: The Standard load balancer supports Private Links; the Basic load balancer does not.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.099
frontText: TRUE or FALSE: The complexity of mapping a Private Link to Azure PaaS services is the same across all resource types and its configuration.
backText: FALSE: It varies with the type and configuration of resources to be mapped to Private Link.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.100
frontText: TRUE or FALSE: Private Link Endpoints can be deployed across different subscriptions and regions as virtual networks.
backText: FALSE: It is not possible; they should be part of the same subscription and region.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.101
frontText: Which cmdlet creates an Azure virtual network?

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.102
frontText: The ____________________ cmdlet creates a probe configuration for an Azure load balancer.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.103
frontText: The _________________________ cmdlet creates a back‐end address pool configuration for an Azure load balancer.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.104
frontText: The __________________________ cmdlet creates a front‐end IP configuration for an Azure load balancer.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.105
frontText: The _________________________________ cmdlet gets a network interface IP configuration from an Azure network interface.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.106
frontText: The ___________________ cmdlet removes an Azure network interface.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.107
frontText: The _____________________cmdlet removes an Azure load balancer.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.108
frontText: The______________________ cmdlet removes an Azure virtual network.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.109
frontText: The____________________ cmdlet adds a subnet configuration to an existing Azure virtual network.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.110
frontText: The________________________ cmdlet gets the virtual network peering.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.111
frontText: The_______________________ cmdlet updates a virtual network.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.112
frontText: The_______________________ cmdlet updates a virtual network tap.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.113
frontText: The Virtual Network Gateway is the object representing your gateway in Azure. The ________________________ cmdlet returns the object of your gateway in Azure based on Name and Resource Group Name.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.114
frontText: The __________________________cmdlet returns a virtual network gateway NAT rule object of your virtual network gateway based on Name and ParentResourceName.

title: fc872924.AzNetEngSG.115
frontText: The _____________________cmdlet sets or updates a virtual network gateway NAT rule.
